That sacred night which spread its starry wings,
(Like curtains shadowing the altar) o'er
Our hymeneal couch, could witness more
Sincerity of indissolving love 'twixt us,
Then does this minute, if your soul,
(Which is so passive it may justly challenge
A martyr's temper) can dispense with passed
Absurd distastes, and like a saint for humane
Condition is too vengeful freely pardon
What I amiss have acted.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: As you are my husband sir, and consequently my head.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.l: How many ladies in town are of that mind.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: And ought to be the guider of my youth,
I will not stand on that nice term of honour,
With you whom duty ties me to observe
With more than superficial care, t'enjoin
A penance for your folly; the light smoke
Finds not a surer burial in the a ire
(To whose embraces with ambitious haste.
On azure wings it soared) then has your guilt,
In this forgiving bosom, this pure kiss seals the agreement.

sp.speaker: Sir Mar.
sp.l: She offered first too, and methought she kissed
As she would eat my lips, the ravenous touch
Of her hot flesh has seared me up like grass
In summer time, and her foul breath like blasts
Of Southern winds, has quickened my dead fire
Of jealousy, nay raised it to a greater
Heat than my former.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: What ail you sir on the sudden?

sp.speaker: Sir Mar.
sp.l: Viper, toad, out of my presence, ere my just waked
Rage, get to its height, whence like a falcon towering
At full pitch o'er the trembling fowl, it will seize on thee.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Madam 'tis best to leave him, I fear he's absolutely frantic; urinal look to him, lest he act some violence on himself, please your ladyship withdraw.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Soft patience guard my heart: where's no offence, one safely may rely on innocence.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: Why sir Martine, how do you sir? not speak? now by my life, he looks like a staggerel newly come to his horns, flings his head just in that manner they do not touch the ceiling, yet sir Martine: in time they may be three and four at top, and serve to hang hats and cloaks on in the best knights hall in town.

sp.speaker: Sir Mar.
sp.p: O urinal.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: O urinal, what a pitiful note was there, that very sound has almost cracked me to pieces: sir Martine, good sir Martine what ails you? or rather what ails your wife, that you hum and haw so after kissing her ▪ her breath is savoury, I dare be sworn she has neither eaten onions nor drunk aquavitae.

sp.speaker: Sir Mar.
sp.l: O no, she is like a too ripe, so extremely sweet,
She poisons like the honey which small bees
Suck from the aconite, the panther so
Breathes odours precious as the Sarmatic gums
Of Eastern groves, but the delicious scent not taken in at
Distance chokes the sense with the too musky savour.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: You should have kissed her as the court fashion is, upon the cheek, but pray sir, why are you so jealous: yet cannot prove your lady has a trick with her toe, or turns oftener than an honest woman (If she do) had not you better like an old stag, cast the cognisance of your order into the hedge, then like a wanton pricket, run full butt at every one you meet, as who should say; take notice of my horns. I am ashamed of it so I am.

sp.speaker: S. Mar.
sp.p: Dost not believe I am? A hideous cuckold.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: And must you needs cry cuckoo therefore. There are knights in town who know their ladies to be hens oth' game, and live by treading, yet like mettle cocks they never hang the gills for't, they are sure fair gamesters use to pay the box well: especially at in, and in, (The inns of court butlers would have had but a bad Christmas of it else) and what care they, so they can purchase plush, though their wives pay ith' hole for it.

sp.speaker: Sir Mar.
sp.p: Can there be such monsters?

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: Monsters, they are men sir Martine, such as you are; only they are velvet browed a little: but hear me sir, if a man would venture fair offer to give a certain knowledge of your wife's honesty.

sp.speaker: Sir Mar.
sp.p: Do that, and be my genius urinal.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: You would have an evil angel of me, I'll tell you sir, my master intends privately this night to wed his daughter to the Dutch younker Sconce, the house will be at-quiet, and your lady left alone in her chamber, her sister mistress Knoworth, being to go to church with them.

sp.speaker: Sir Mar.
sp.p: What of this?

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: Soft and fair sir Martine, I will ith' evening steal you into the lady's chamber when she's in bed, come to her, and in the dark, (That's the only time to deal with a woman) (And as another man) try what you can do with her: if she consent (The worst) you do but cuckold yourself, if hold out, being a woman alone, in bed, and in the dark having a man standing by her, you may then conclude her an honest wife, and your jealousy foolish, as your vexation needless, you think I have no wit now I warrant.

sp.speaker: Sir Mar.
sp.p: According as my soul could wish.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p:
Why la you then, who's the fool now? Sir Martine
come in the evening, I will not fail you.

sp.speaker: Sir Mar.
sp.l: Nor I hopes of trial, fare you well,
A jealous man has in his heart his hell.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: Well knight, if I do not fit your jealous head, let me be sung in ballads for an erranter coxcomb than yourself.

div.stage: Enter mistress Artless, mistress Mixum, and Dalinea.

sp.speaker: Mistress Art.
sp.p: Well said minx, you will not have him: but you had best consider and do as I and your father would have you: or you shall trudge for it, you shall be his wife.

sp.speaker: Mistress Mix.
sp.p: Nay in sadness mistress Dal. you are too blame, the gentleman is an honest gentleman, I and a kind man I warrant him to a woman; your mother and I have made trial of him, and find him of a very good disposition, come chick you shall have him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Art.
sp.p: Nay let her choose and be hanged, proud baggage who will refuse a gentleman of my own choosing, but I'll send him to you and see if thou dar'st deny him, for thy life, come mistress Mixum.

div.stage: Exeunt mistress Artless and mistress Mixum.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: Was ever innocent virgin thus betrayed
By cruelty of parents, who for wealth
Have sold my youth to slavery, the cold
Ashes of injured maids surround my heart,
Or some divine dew, stead of blood replenish
My swelling veins, circle my thought with ice,
Thou power of chastity, that like the fresh
Primrose uncropped, by any hand, I may
Return myself as pure and white
To earth, as when I came from't.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: How do you mistress Dal. alas poor gentlewoman, would they have thee covered with a Friesland horse, a Dutch stallion: now shame upon their souls that wish it, he's neighing here already.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p:
Urinal, my cousin fortress and the rest oth' knights will be here presently; pray you prepare the music and the wine,
I would not fail in the most diminute ceremony.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: Of a most absolute coxcomb, I shall provide them sir.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Now begins my horror, the fatal bell should it proclaim my death, were sphere-like music to his night-crow's voice; yet I must hear it and retain my sense, continue subject to a daily noise from the ill boding monster.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: Lady or mademoiselle, ufroe or seniora, what you please, or in what language to be entitled the mistress of my thoughts, the complemental garb is customary, and though I have learned by conversation with the Twibill knights to kiss my hand, believe me I had rather bestow my lips on yours; our natural Dutch contracting is the best, without deceit or shadow, there we only go to th' tavern and be ungue browed, then drunk together. There's all our ceremony, and 'tis lawful marriage too.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Would you would sir, better consider with yourself and match where your own customs are observed, my fear my quality will never suit the liking of your Dutch manners.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: Manner's lady, you mistake I've none at all; ere we will disagree about manners, I'll be as clownish as an upland bore, foutra, tell a Dutch man of manners?

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Yet sir have so much charity.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: We detest that worse than the former, 'tis papistical, and was with that religion banished our reformed commonwealth: but to our business, pretty soul, I shall give thee touch mon and get a burger of thee.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: Gentle sir, there ought to be in manhood a divine
Pity, believe me as I tender truth,
I cannot set the smallest of my thoughts
On your ill welcome love, therefore I beseech you
Not to proceed in my unfortunate match
Which will be fatal to us both, for goodness
Have so much mercy on me.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p:
An excellent touch that, as if there could be mercy in a Dutchman, and to a woman? if there had been any, the nuns at Tilmont had not been used so horribly last summer: why should you say you cannot love me 'tis a false touch I me certain of it, I shall know anon, till when receive your lips in pledge
that no such words shall issue forth of them, adieu lady, anon we must to the old touch of matrimony.

sp.speaker: Dal
sp.l: The hand of death
Shall give me first a bride to some dark grave,
Where I will mix with worms before the priest
Knit so unjust an union, the kind grass
Will sure be green still on my sepulchre, and spotless
Virgins annually dance a fairy ring about it.

div.stage: Enter Urinal and Popingay in disguised clothes.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: Now if you do not catch a roach in her troubled waters, I shall conclude you a gudgeon: speak to her; a woman has ever a hole open to receive a man's tale, believe it you shall have my assistance, and if I do not second you confidently, may my tongue be cramped, my wit breeched; and the machina of my invention ruined perpetually.

sp.speaker: Pop.
sp.p: Fairest creature.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: Had you said wretched'st, mistress you had given me
My proper attribute.

sp.speaker: Pop.
sp.l: Can there be on earth,
A savageness so great as will conspire
To afflict so rich a goodness? yet by your eyes
Adorned by those clear pearls which do transform
Even sorrow to a loveliness beyond
Indifferent beauty, I conceive some fiend
Rested in humane shape (For man would never
Have dared so vile a sacrilege) in hope
By your pure tears, t'extinguish his own flames
Caused this distemper in you.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.l: Pish you are long to speed, be
Short and quick, that pleases ladies.

sp.speaker: Pop.
sp.l: I had a younger brother, though not fully blessed
In your sweet knowledge, yet once his tongue
Was his hearts bold ambassador, and delivered
A true narration of his zealous love,
Which is in him so permanent, that when
His ears receive a notice that your faith
is plighted to another, 'twill be juice
Of baleful hemlock to his brain, convert it
Either to sudden madness or asleep , cold and everlasting.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: I remember once a nephew of sir Martin's did solicit
That which he termed my love, but I conceived
His meaning rather was to cause discourse,
Then that his strict intention had resolved
His promises performance.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.l: Did I not tell you she would come about?

sp.speaker: Pop.
sp.l: Trust me lady, the solitary nightingale who sings
To her lost honour a harmonious ditty,
Loves not the thorn so dear, to whose pricks
She sets her feathered bosom, as I me sure
My brother tenders you, the gawdy light
May sooner be obscured by wand'ring smoke:
Nay the eternal essence of the soul
Become corporeal and revisit earth,
After its flight to paradise, ere he
Descend to variation of his love, could you affect him.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: Had your brother been
Of the same disposition and soft sweetness
That I perceive in you (Though this be our
First interview) there could not have been moulded
(Had I been born to entertain loves heat)
A man that would so fitly sympathize
With my condition, nor whom I should fancy
With more entire perfection.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.l: Strike home, and sure the iron's hot already,

sp.speaker: Pop.
sp.l: Behold him lady,
Whose every motion does as from the sphere,
Receive a lively influence from your looks;
The modest silence of the temperate even,
When Zephire softly murmurs to the flowers
A wholesome farewell undisturbed by storms,
May sooner rest in one continued night,
Then can my soul in quiet without just
Assurance of your love, which if you grant,
Times native bellman, the shield Organd cock
shall cease to carol matins to the morn,
The ●arely lark that whispers to the sun
A constant augury of a beauteous day,
Shall lose his light plumes in the checkered clouds,
Ere I my resolute chastity ▪ nor can you
Invent evasions to declare my suit,
Since on its grant relies the only hopes
Of your redemption from the barbarous arms,
Of him you were espoused to.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: This surprise,
And your strong vows would batter a resolve,
Down in a breast that could be flexible
To easy love, but since I cannot frame
My conscience to a warrantable zeal
Towards any man, I'll rather fix my hate
(For that must of necessity accrue
To him that weds me) on a person worthy
Contempt, then on yourself, whose wor●● does challenge
A noble and reciprocal regard
For your affection, blessings on ye sir, think not amiss of me.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: Now the curse of a tedious virginity light on ye, you will not be tupped by a Dutch ram, a Hausen kender, a Westphaly boar-pig, now the iniquity of a swag-bellied Holland's burghers get thee with child of a dropsy, if thou marriest him, why how now master Popingay, strooken with a planet? 'tis a female star, as changeable as the moon, go to your chamber, I hear company approaching, this Dutch butter-firkin shall be melted to grease ere he shall have her, trust to it.

sp.speaker: Pop.
sp.l: Passion on passion fall when hopes are spent,
The best of comforts is a forced content.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.l: So here comes my blades, now plot but hit,
And urinal shall be styled the lord of wit.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p:
Cousin fortress welcome, welcome captain Pirke, valiant brothers, nay gentlemen, than your accoutrements be of
the vulgar cut, be not daunted, 'tis hereditary to low country soldiers to wear off reckonings, the time shall come the little worm shall weave, and silken tribute pay to men of service, give me your hands gentlemen, I shall be one of you anon, but cousin Fortresse, what bashful youth is that that dares not thrust his nose out of his coat, for fear the wind should blow it to his face, ha?

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.p: 'Tis flat enough already, this my Jo, nay show thy phisnomy, he's our quondam trusty attendant, but now knight of the Twibill, Pythagoras big.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: Is this the famous offspring of great hog? we should be kindred certainly, my ancestors were boars, give me thy fore-foot sirrah, and tell me coz, why dost not wander into a new skin? this begins to crackle vilely.

sp.speaker: Pirk.
sp.p: O 'tis for want of basting sir.

sp.speaker: For●.
sp.p: No my Jo, he casts his skin but once a year, like the poor snake: well, he has done our order special service; but coz, where are the preparations the van-courier's coz, to the solemnity of your installment? renounce me, if you vilify the institution by disregard of properties, this hand shall never cross the Twibill o'er thy head, nor give thee thy avant chevalier, while thou art mortal my Jo, I say I shall not.

sp.speaker: Pirk.
sp.p: No matter sir sconce, by the head of valour, myself shall dub thee.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.p: Who you King twaddle? Mushroom you dub him?

sp.speaker: Pirk.
sp.p: Yes, I gog, Magog, I dub him Garantua.

sp.speaker: Scon
sp.p: Nay good cousin fortress, captain Pirke, this urinal I could e'en fill him to the brim with curses, but here's my agent; come where are the musicianers urinal?

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: They will be loud enough by and by, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.p: This is legitimate blood of the Spanish grape my Jo.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: Lusty sack credit me coz, 'twill give the touch, urinal make fast the door, and leave us, and give us notice if anybody approach.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: What haste this gull makes to cheat himself in private, must the music enter?

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.l: No by no means, we'll call to them through the door, varlet avoid.
Now coz, to begin our ceremony; first, drink to me.

sp.speaker: Scon:
sp.p: I like it well when it begins with drinks, 'tis a sign 'twill end merrily; this cup is abominable too little, one can scarce wet his whistle out of it, it shall be this goblet, a vostre grace, coz fortress.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.p: Sir Pythagoras we do create you skinker, it shall go round my blades, you shall dible in liquor of account; here brother makeshift.

sp.speaker: Make,
sp.p: Gramercies captain.

sp.speaker: Pirk.
sp.p: Choke you sir, learn manners, offer to drink before betters, 'tis an affront to seniority, destroy me if I can suffer this, no forsake me captain I cannot.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: There was a touch for you brother makeshift, but good little Pirke be patient.

sp.speaker: Mak.
sp.p: This preface is very canonical my Io, nay, I shall learn the phrases instantly.

sp.speaker: Pig.
sp.p: Have you all had it brothers?

sp.speaker: Pig.
sp.p: All but myself sir Holofernes.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: Who my coz big, off sup off thy wash my Jo, at worst thou canst but be swine-drunk; but coz, shall we dispatch? I long to be installed.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.p: I now we'll to't, come hither captain, sing the hymn preparatory to knighthood, but wet your pipes first, Ganymede, they'll squeak the better.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: An admirable touch this, what's next trow?

sp.speaker: Fort
sp.p: Now coz sconce, our order does constrain us to a frisk, a dance about you, as the fairies tread about their great King Oberon.

sp.speaker: Pirk.
sp.p: But can this music play the Twibill dance, none else will satisfy.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: Music you must play the Twibill dance he says, dance so while.

sp.speaker: Dance.
sp.p: They dance, the wine shall tread a sink apace into my belly, you have lost one of your best heels cousin.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.p: No me Jo, 'twas off before the ceremony is half accomplished, you are our wardrobe keeper, brother Knockedowne have you brought the vestments of our order?

sp.speaker: Knocke.
sp.p: Fuse captain not I.

sp.speaker: Pirk.
sp.p: Rot me sir, you would be made to fetch them.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: How, not our robes of honour the ensigns of our chevalry?

sp.speaker: Knock.
sp.p: Sink me, sir you know they are in tribulation.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Hell take the broker: we must perforce employ one of our own suits.

sp.speaker: Knock
sp.p: Take my buff jerkin captain.

sp.speaker: Make.
sp.p: Death keep it on, you'll show your dirty shirt.

sp.speaker: Pirke.
sp.p: Found you sir, you lie: I fathom in your guts, he has none on.

sp.speaker: Make.
sp.p: How, son of foul adultery, the lie?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: What do you blunder, whifflers pig, are you grunting too: shall I whet my Twibill on your bones mips of debility?

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: Nay, cousin, gentlemen rather than you shall fall out, I'll be content to be dubbed in my own clothes: nay pray you gentlemen.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: 'Tis against order, and we must observe ceremony.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: O by all means coz.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: First then receive this cap of maintenance.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: Cap of maintenance do you call it? I will maintain when this old cap was new, 'twas a Dutch felt, but now 'tis nine degrees below a straw hat; I do not like this touch: but coz I shall have my beaver again I hope?

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.p: How? suspicious my Io: brother Knockdowne disrobe his neck of this old linen, savours of a winding-sheet: this is decimo sexto, fears no rumpling: now cousin sconce, you must discuss your doublet.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: That will be damned instantly; pray heaven my skin scape.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Here sir, receive this military cassock, 't has seen service.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: 'Thas been shot through both the elbows; this military cassock has I fear, some military hang-byes: this Twibill knighthood is but a lousy order, would I had ne'er meddled with it.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.p: Now you appear something above an embryo: makeshift help to untruss his breeches.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: I shall be whipped instantly: but cousin fortress, is there no redemption for my breeches?

sp.speaker: Pirke.
sp.p: Sum me captain, 'tis not requisite he should put off his breeches.

sp.speaker: Scon
sp.p: Thanks good captain Pirke, 'twas a friendly touch that

sp.speaker: Pir.
sp.p: May not his transitory money serve to excuse his breeches?

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.p: To him it may.

sp.speaker: Pir.
sp.p: A Twibill knight ought to regard no money, but the glistering steel.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: Well, since it must be so, there take my money.

sp.speaker: Knock.
sp.p: Paw sir, you lose the privilege of the order, if you respect your money.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: Now do I look like — as if I were new come from the lottery: or what say you sir Holofernes, to the picture of the prodigal in the painted cloth? Sure I have now performed all the ceremonies; if not, I me sure I have nothing else left to perform withal.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.p: So, now kneel down, while thus I thee create: Jeremias sconce, knight of the order of Twibill. Now avaunt chevalier.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Health to our worthy brother, Jeremias sconce, knight of the Twibill.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.p: But brothers, there is sack yet to be drunk, in celebration of this knighthood,

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: I like this drinking heartily; there's some goodness in't: will you begin, my captain general; I'll call you so now.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.p: Pythagoras, fill his bowl up. Captain. Pirk this cornucopia to my lieutenant general's health: I'll call you so now.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: A place of mark and charge that.

sp.speaker: Pirke.
sp.p: Man of valour, respect this cup to the health of our leift, general.

sp.speaker: M●rk.
sp.p: A vous brother Knockdowne.

sp.speaker: Knock.
sp.p: Here sir Barrabas.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: Altogether gentlemen, a health musicians,Sound.gentlemen all tres humblement serviture vostre: I ha' done you right.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.p: Expect me Io; heart of my father, you must for consummation of your instalment, drink a cup a piece to each of us.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: 'Twas my intention general: to you all in general, help pith. let it be be two captain, 'tis pity to put so many worthy men in a pint pot.

sp.speaker: Perk.
sp.p: Soul of my valour, you're shipped sir, you must drink five together.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: You're wanton captain, a wag upon my knighthood, you mean to measure the profundity of my belly, 'twill be a hard task to do it to a Dutchman — look you captain.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.p: Thou shalt be my Bacchus io, he drinks as if he had eaten pickle herring.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: This cup was as deep as Fleetstreet conduit. Sound me my Io, I ha' made a new river in my belly, and my guts are the pipes: tother cup good wreckling, virtue shall be virtue still, so long as I can stand captain.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.p: That will not be long I hope.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: This choler spoils my drinking, or else this sack has horseflesh in't, it rides upon my stomach. O urinal, I'm a knight of the Twibill honest urinal.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: Take heed you'll crush me sir to pieces. Gentlemen yonder are the constables at the door to apprehend captain fortress.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: Some more sack sirrah, I shall be married anon.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: That's I, 'tis for the linen brothers: hell my Io, how shall I scape them?

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: More sack sirrah, the tother touch sweet big, the tother touch.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: There is no way but one sir, they have beset the house; my master is persuading them. Follow me, I'll by a back way set you safely out with your company.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Noble urinal: come blades here's purchase for us.

sp.speaker: Scor.
sp.p: This is but four cups captain cousin pig. Skinke my parting cup, and then I me gone: ha! where be you gentlemen, I am not blind, or play you at boe-peep? they are gone, this is a pretty touch, my touch my Io, with my money and clothes, a prettier touch still, let me see, they have left some sack behind them, there's my comfort yet.
sp.stage: E●t. Popin. and louring in woman's clothes.
sp.l: Who's this? my wife that must be.
Come hither wife, thou seest the worst of me
sp.p: I am but drunk: kiss me Borankee: never fear, I will not spoil thy gorget. Hark in thy ear my Io, shall I have a gentle touch? 'twill do no harm, we are to be married anon thou knowest; I shall get wise children on thee.

sp.speaker: Lo●
sp.p: What wouldst thou ravish me libidinous swine? Strive, and thou diest.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: 'Twas an unkind touch that, my Io, you might have fallen under me, 't had been the fitter place for a woman, (Pray help me up again.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Yes, to thy death, if thou deny to perform what I enjoin thee.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: How, kill a knight of the Twibill, and in the ensigns of his own order, ere it shall be said to the disgrace of knighthood, that any of the fraternity was killed by a woman, I'll do any thing: lead on, I'll follow you.

sp.speaker: Pop.
sp.l: Thus they must strive ▪
Who in loves subtle merchandise will thrive.

div.head: Actus quintus, scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter doctor, Urinal, mrit, Artless, and Mris. Mixum.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: This stealth was unexpected, 'tis almost
Beyond belief, my daughter should thus change
Her perverse humour, and embrace his love
Which when I motioned to her, the dark shade
Seemed not a greater enemy to blessed light
Than she appeared to it: and that she should
Cozen my hopes, and without me her mother,
Or any friend resign her will to his,
And strike the match up, puzzles my best faith,
Though I rejoice at it.

sp.speaker: ●rin
sp.p:
You have reasons sir to do so, your daughter had more wit than you expected, 'tis the quality of maids, to deny what they desire: had you but seen how nimbly she trod over the threshold; you would have sworn she had been mad of the match: I stood and heard him ask her: shall we go to the
church 〈…〉 not too late 〈…〉 ●oo late to do well replied she again: (Though it were at midnight) and then the Dutch you 〈◊〉 took her up into a (What do you call it) a sedan (And heaven speed) away they went, marry to what church, he's gone I know not, only I heard him swear he would not come at Pencridge.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Art.
sp.p: And why not; 'tis an ancient church, and all old things must not be cast away ▪ there has been many an honest couple given to the lawful bed there, so there has.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: No matter for that, he protested he would be married in a tavern ere that pencridge, there's no drink ne'er it; but at the pinner of Wakefield, and that's abominable, and he has vowed to season their bargain with a cup of sack ere they return.

sp.speaker: Mistress Art.
sp.p: He will not be drunk on's wedding night I hope; my daughter would have a sweet bedfellow of him, if he should.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: There is another loving couple gone with them too for company, who will be man and wife if the priest say amen to it.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Who are they of our knowledge?

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: O yes sir, 'tis master Lovering, the attendant to master Knoworth, and sir Martine's niece that came but yesterday.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Is't possible? 'twas some sly policy of her uncles to bring her hither, master Lovering knew her before it seems.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: Too well I fear sir, they would not have married in such post haste else.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mix.
sp.p: Well master doctor, I hope my gloves shall be better than the ordinary, I had no small hand in this match, you know.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: 'Tis nine o'clock at least: 'twill not belong ere they return, wife pray go in and see all things in readiness for their lodgings.

sp.speaker: Mistress Art.
sp.p: They will have more stomachs to their beds then to their suppers.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Tomorrow we'll celebrate their nuptial feast: urinal be you careful of the doors ▪ let none come in but our own company.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: I'll lock them up, and keep the keys myself sir, Mrs. Mixum your husband is with them, and in his absence I would desire a word with you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mix.
sp.p: I love to talk with any man in my husband's absence; sweet urinal I will fulfil your pleasure, will you go mistress?
sp.stage: Ex. Urin. Mrs. Art. and Mrs. Mix.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: So now have at her.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Have I not plotted finely? has my brain
Not won the laurel garland the famed breath
That wafts the honour of deserving wits
Among the humorous multitude (As loud
As it speaks conquering triumphs) shall proclaim
My politic merit, who have raised myself
From worse than no name in the judging world,
To an indifferent wealth, which though● ye got
By ways sinister, such as err from truth:
Nay might incur a punishment no eyes
Has ere discerned them, but with wonder how
I should achieve such fortune, now complete
In this alliance.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Sister, let's to our chambers and to bed,
That time approaches.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Your good ladyship (I hope) will honour me so much
As for an hour to dispense with rest ▪
And see my bride in bed.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Your bride good master doctor, who should that be?
I understand you not.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: My daughter ladies, that to me
And all the house seemed so averse from marriage,
Is this night stolen forth with younker sconce,
And is by this time wedded to him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Beyond wonder, well sir,
We'll have her bride garters, it shall go
Hard else, sister could you have thought it?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: You may both credit it, instantly they will return, and
Then I'll wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I pity the poor girl,
That she should be so sudden in her choice,
Enthrall her soul ith' manacles of fate,
(For such are nuptial bonds) experience sister
Enforces me to lament her Know

sp.speaker: Know●
sp.l: How equally we two
Divide true, sorrow sympathize in grief,
As in our blood and nature: sister you
When your affectionate fancy fixed your heart
Upon your husband's love, had no suspicion
Of his unmanly jealousy, and I
When I confined my love to free Freewit's breast ▪
Judged him as void of falsehood, as the spring
When it has rested in green robes the earth is
Of bare nakedness, but we are both
Deceived by our credulity ▪

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: For you, discretion may release you from the care
Of his affection, you are free (As light)
(Which in the darkest night retains some splendour)
From the obedient slavery, due to marriage;
But I no burn-marked captive is engaged
With more officious zeal to serve his lord,
Than I my husband, I must either perish
Like the chaste ice, when from a Christ all rock,
It feels a sad conversion into foul
Corrupted waters, by his jealous flames;
Or break those ties whose dissolution
Would betray my innocent virtue to a ruin,
Sure and eternal.

sp.speaker: Know ▪
sp.l: But yet counsel me,
I love this man so that if honour would
Dispense with his offence, I should forgive him,
And take him to my bosom

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Alas you cannot,
What noble soul (Though half starved) would be fed with
Base reversions, conscience too forbids.
The supplantation of another, sister strive to forget him

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: Mrs. there is a gentleman without, this knocked for entrance as if he had been a constable, his business is with you, and his name free●it; I told him you were in bed and he swore he would come to you through the door, shall I admit him?

sp.speaker: Know.
sp.p: This is his last night, his business carries weight, pray let him in. Be now propitious love: is any with him?

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: There is enough of him, unless he made less noise. I'll send him to you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Sister, now give him his latest answer, and resolve
Upon some choice more happy: here he comes.

sp.speaker: Know.
sp.l: How, as a bridegroom?
Decked with the ensigns of young nuptials,
A wreath of flowers, and bays, and yet methinks
His hand displays a willow: what should this emblem?
Master Freewit we scarce expected you thus late.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: You'll please to afford my manners an indulgent pardon,
For pressing to your presence thus: but 'tis
Perhaps our extremest interview, and so
May challenge the prerogative of excuse,
For the audacious error.

sp.speaker: Know.
sp.p: Would I could, with as much safety to my honour, grant remission to your other fault.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: My thanks, are humble debtors to you for it, mistress,
The nimble minutes have with crafty theft,
Stolen time away, reduced your limited hour
To an unwelcome period: I have sought
With the same diligence good men seek heaven,
What you enjoined me, but the rain that falls
In summer time upon the parched dust,
May easier be restored to the moist clouds,
Than she to my discovery. Wherefore since
Her loss is certain, and the loss of you
Depends on her, to satisfy your soul
That I have man about me, I am come
With the same confidence your scorn has taught me,
To tell you, I as lightly prize your love,
As you have valued mine● nor can you blame me, since 'twas your own desire.

sp.speaker: Know.
sp.l: Credit me I'm very glad on't: but pray tell me sir,
Why you come thus adorned with nuptial wreathes
Into my presence? is't to invite me to your wedding, or expression
Of your contempt, I have not merited so harsh an usage.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Neither: this branch of forsaken willow I resign
To your own wearing, that when after times
shall know our ●●tuall parting; 't may report,
That we were both forsaken, though we sever
With the unwillingness that flourishing trees,
Divest themselves of greenness, yet no blemish
Of harsh unkindness shall defile our thoughts:
We'll part fair, though for ever.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: This gentleman seems so noble, I repent that I advised her from him.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: This laurel wreath, that circles
My uncaptived brow, I do justly challenge,
Since I have conquered the greatest enemy,
Mankind can combat (Passion) yet the dew
(That on the red lips of the blushing rose
Bestows a weeping kiss) leaves not so sadly
The amorous flower, that curls its purple leaves,
To hide it from the suns enforcing rays,
As do my thoughts your memory, which did once
Preserve it as inviolable, as heaven
Does the bright souls of innocents.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: You might
Have had so much humanity, as to have kept
Your purpose to yourself: though your loose sin
Constrains my honour to renounce your love,
I would not have my ears disturbed with this
Relation of your contempt, for so
Trust me I take it Freewit.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Why, good madam? can you condemn my too officious truth,
Of a conceit of falsehood, when the spring
Of my revolt, derives its head from yours.
You for a trivial, and scarce known offence,
Could without scruple banish me your heart,
When angels should, for a desertless kiss
From an impure lip, have renounced their bliss,
Ere the most urgent reason of suspect,
Should upon me have practised a contempt
Of you: had not your breath exposed a mist
Of infidelity before the eyes
Of my clear seeing soul, and left it blind
As the black mole, that like a pioneer digs
A winding labyrinth through the earth to find
A passage to the comfortable light,
He never has fruition of.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: But sir, suppose my sister did it for a proof,
Of your affection, and now should reclaim
The harsh prescription she imposed, you would not
Continue in this temper.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Madam ever. The cedars juice, whose bitter poison gives
The most strong body unavoided death,
Preserves the carcase by its dying force,
Void of corruption: so has dealt her love
With me; its reclamation struck me dead,
And since my exequies has kept my heart
From entertaining a corrupt regard
Of future slavery,

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: They are entered, sir, I heard Mr. mix. say as I let them in, that they were married.

div.stage: Enter Mixum with a Torch, popinjays in Sconce his clothes, leading Dalinea: Lovering leading Sconce attired in poping. woman's clothes.

sp.speaker: Mix.
sp.p: Nay, come an end gentlemen and your wives, Mr. doctor will not be angry though I have usurped his office, and been the father to his daughter.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: You are not a cunning baggager you would none forsooth when I proposed it to you; but when the fit came on you, you could then run madding, and never let the sexton ring the bell to give us notice: had it been any one but Mr. sconce, you should have fought a portion; but since to him, we pardon it: take her son, heavens give thee joy of her.

sp.speaker: Vri.
sp.p: You would scarce say so, knew you as much as I do.

sp.speaker: Pop.
sp.p: We thank you sir, and rest your dutiful children.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Ha● my nephew Popingay!

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Mr. popingays. Sir Maritime's nephew! I am abused, undone, my daughter's cozened urinal, a trick put on me, Mr. Popingay to wed my daughter.

sp.speaker: Pop.
sp.p: ● was with her own consent sir, and she my wife by your free gift.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Art.
sp.p: Your wife, your whore she is as soon, she is master sconces wife, and that you shall find, so you shall, let me come to the baggage husband, 〈…〉 her eyes out.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Ere he shall enjoy her, I'll spend the best part of my wealth he shall not have a penny portion with her, depart my house I charge you urinal call in my neighbours, ere I'll he used thus ▪

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: 〈…〉 I know you and your ways.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: Go to, be patient, then give this gentleman your daughter; nay be friends, and love him too, or all shall out.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Thou wilt not betray me villain?

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.l: But I shall discover you and your practises, nay to the justice,
This gentleman is the same sir Martin brought hither as his niece.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Plots upon plots against me.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: But the great one is still behind: if you will be friends quickly with them, so; if not, your impostures all come out.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Is it even so? well since I am o'erreached.
Better sit down in peace, than with disgrace:
Mr. Popingay consideration of your just desert,
Now his persuasion has suppressed my heat,
Enjoins me to forgive your loving theft ▪
Accept my daughter with as good a heart
As she is mine: come hither wife, say you so too?

sp.speaker: Mr●s. Art.
sp.p: Nay, since you say it, it must be so.

sp.speaker: Pop.
sp.l: Humbly I thank you: such another gift,
Should nature offer all her precious store,
Could not be given mortality: but truly sir ▪
I had much ado to win her.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: You have me now;
But I profess until we came to be
Conjoined ith' church, I took you for Mr. Sconce, but now rejoice
I was deceived so, I shall study to love you▪

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Now you name, where is Mr. sconce?

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: 'Tis my cue now. O father I me here they have given me a touch, a very scurvy touch, I am a brother of the Twibills, and I am married too, but I need not fear being a cuckold.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: Mrs. you know the gent.

sp.speaker: Know.
sp.l: My servant Lovering married to Mr. sconce!
You'll get brave boys I doubt not.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: I and wenches too; come hither, we will be man and wife, that's certain, nay and lie together, so we will, you shall behave yourself well enough like a woman: but that you have a stiff impediment forbearing children: but give me thy hand, shall's be drunk together?

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: He is scarce sober yet I think.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p:
●e tell you father, ere I ▪ went to the church I had gotten a touch in the crown, the Twibill knights confusion them on my Jo had made me drunk, and got my 〈…〉 by these
I know not: but ha, let me see, this should be my suit, 'tis it, by valour it is: do you hear good man fox, how crept you into this lion's case?

sp.speaker: Pop.
sp.p: What means this new married man?

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: Do you jeer me, with a touch of that? hark you husband, though I be your wife, you shall not hinder me from claiming my own breeches. Mistress a word with you too you put a gentle touch upon me did you not? But I shall know you hereafter, I'll say no more, and touch you boldly for it.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: You're very merrily disposed sir: had it not been to have done sir Martin's nephew, I should not have been fooled so. I'll try his temper though.

sp.speaker: Know.
sp.l: No matter Lovring thou art a gent.
And since I am resolved from master Freewit,
That he'll not have me now, (Though I were willing)
To toot the least remembrance of him
Out of my breast, by this my happier choice,
I'll marry thee.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: But let him marry you though if he dare, I'll sue the statute of bigamy upon him, he shall be hanged for being double married.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: In this one act
She only appears woman, all her saint,
Speak her a saint. I did not think her heart
Could have resumed (Though than rejected me)
A baser choice, sir you've good fortune: mrs.
I will not wish you ill success in your
So sudden love: but it was cruel in you
To give away your soul, (As in despite)
In my loathed presence: yet to show how much
I prize your satisfaction, I resign
My interest in you to him, and thus freely
Bestow him on you: will you have him lady▪

div.stage: Pulls of loverings periwigs, he is discovered to be Marth●.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Heaven bless me sister, this is the same maid
Whom master Freewit is reported to have
Got with child: this is strange▪

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Nay, be not amazed mistress it is she:
You had best call her to a strict account
How long 'tis since I lay with her.
〈◊〉 Freewit, what means this mad delusion?

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: My wife turned a woman indeed: this is a touch indeed, I had best be gone, for fear she challenge me.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: O stay your patience good Mr. sconce.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Now let heaven, and all that can be titled good beneath
Divinity, conjoin to frame a piece
Of virtue great as this; yet be deficient
In the achievement ▪ for some cunning artist
To draw her in this posture (To be placed
(In alabaster, white as her own figure)
Or some green mead or flowery valley, where
Posterity of virgin's yearly might
Offer a tear to the blessed memory
Of perfect feminine goodness. Let me die,
Gazing on you and I shall fly to heaven
Through your bright eyes.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Sir, what means this ecstasy?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: I'll tell you, and Mrs trust each word ▪
As the just accent of oraculous truth:
Knowing your and e●t love to me, I feared
It might embrace a change, and therefore shaped this woman
In the habit of a man got her unknown to you,
Preferred to serve you: (Which she could not have been without
Discovery, in her own shape) not to o'erlook your life.
Or watch your actions, but to raise report
That I had been false: so to try if that
Would stagger your resolve, which I have found
So noble, that the happiness of fates,
Can give no more addition to my bliss.
Madam beg you my pardon.

sp.speaker: Know.
sp.l: O sir you have it, and I my best of wishes, but why did you
Employ a woman thus disguised suppose
She had been got with child you must
Have been the father of it.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: I knew she was too honest, and beside,
I put her to the acting of't because
She being the accuser of me for herself
Might without the least scruple of suspect
Free me from her own calumny, nay here's another,
Can witness this for truth.

sp.speaker: Know
sp.p:
How urinal master: doctor's man turned to 〈◊〉 Mr.
Freewit's man, and Martha's brother?

sp.speaker: Vrin
sp.p: So it appears by the story Mrs. I am glad sir you put my sister in this disguise, she has got a good husband by the shift, take your wife sir, she is no worse a woman than my own sister.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: But let me see and feel you better, it is no periwig this but are you my husband, a woman; wife?

sp.speaker: Liv
sp.p: I your wife am sir.

sp.speaker: Sc●n.
sp.p: Master doctor you wish me well I know, I have married here I know not whom, you have excellent salves and unguents sir.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: They are at your service all.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: Thank you good Mr. doctor, have you never a one that will eat off the wen of manhood, make all whole before that will eunuchise a man, I would fain be a Hermaphrodite , or a woman to escape this match, I do not like it

sp.speaker: Mris. Mix.
sp.p: Help gentlemen, help Mr. doctor, yonder is a man would ravish me whether I would or no, nay killed me, I think he has pulled out the longest naked weapon, oh there he is.

sp.speaker: S. Mar.
sp.l: She shall not scape me were she
Fenced with fire, strumpet thou diest.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Who's this, sir Martin, what do you mean sir?

sp.speaker: Mris.
sp.p: Ay, this is he Thomas do you see what a terrible thing he has got? was that fit to use to a woman? I was but laid in the next room, to sleep, and he would have done something to me so he would had not I been the honester woman.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Is't so sir Martine? I have now just cause
To suspect your loyalty, and that your fond
Jealousy proceeds out of intemperate lust,
Could I not serve, but underneath my nose
You must be rioting upon another?

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Shame and confusion seize me.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: You may see sir what comes of your jealousy, but fear not sir, your wife will pardon it, there's no harm done.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mix.
sp.p: But there might have been, had not my honesty been the greater.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.l: Well sir Martine, though you have injured
Me most infinitely, I do re●●t all if you will protest
Ne'er to be jealous more.

sp.speaker: S. Mar.
sp.l: Amazement and my shame hinders my utterance,
Let me breath in sighs my true repentance,
And henceforth
That jealousy in man if't be injust
Is ill, nay worse than in a woman's lust.

sp.speaker: Know.
sp.l: But pray you brother, who brought you hither?
We shall rejoice to have you at our wedding,
And see this reconcilement.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: I madam, I; under pretence to have attempted his wife, but I sent him in to Mrs. Mixum, who I knew would fit his turn.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mix.
sp.p: And so I could have suited him as well as another woman.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: Brother urinal you are a knave, brother urinal, and have showed all a cozening touch.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: No sir I saved you from being cozened, my sister shall have some portion, here's a hundred pieces in this purse.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: Sink me my ●o, my own purse.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: It, is indeed sir, I got it from your Twibill brothers, and this your watch too, and your clothes which Mr. Popingay wears, by locking them into a room, and threatening punishment, if● they denied, the blades shall now resume freedom ▪ this key will let them out, come forth gentlemen, here is your brother master sconce.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: Captain general, give thy hand bully, captain Pirke, my cousin big, and all of you; though you would have cheated me 'tis no matter, you shall dance at my wedding, and be drunk too, my Joe, you shall.

sp.speaker: Pirk.
sp.p: Confusion rot the bones of urinal perdition shall slay him;

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Madam I hope we shall keepe our nuptial feast with master doctor.

sp.speaker: Know.
sp.p: As you dispose it sir, I have resigned my will to yours.

sp.speaker: Pop.
sp.p: Uncle I hope you'll pardon me, that I deceived your expectation in watching my aunt, she is too virtuous: father your blessing, and then we are happy.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Take it.
Thus all are pleased I hope: what this night cannot
(For celebration of these feasts) perform,
Tomorrow shall, and from this minute I
Renounce all ways sinister to get wealth
Things that ith' period prosperously succeed,
Though crossed before, are acted well indeed.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
